title: 108_hr503
content: The new section 45G provides a tax credit for producing oil and gas from marginal wells. The new section 45G provides a tax credit for producing oil and gas from marginal wells. The credit amount is $3 per barrel of qualified crude oil production and 50 cents per 1,000 cubic feet of qualified natural gas production, with reductions as oil and gas prices increase. The tax credit amount for producing oil and gas from marginal wells is determined based on the excess of the applicable reference price over $15 ($1.67 for qualified natural gas production) and $3 ($0.33 for qualified natural gas production). The reference price is for the calendar year preceding the taxable year, and dollar amounts are adjusted for inflation after 2003. The tax credit amount for qualified crude oil and natural gas production is determined by multiplying the dollar amount by the inflation adjustment factor for the calendar year, using the reference price for each type of production. Qualified crude oil and natural gas production refers to domestic production from marginal wells, with a limit of 1,095 barrels per taxable year per well. Definitions for marginal well are provided in relation to limitations on production for wells not in production for the entire year. The term 'marginal well' refers to a domestic well with specific production criteria. A domestic well is considered a marginal well if it has average daily production of not more than 25 barrel equivalents and produces water at a rate not less than 95 percent of total well effluent. The terms 'crude oil', 'natural gas', 'domestic', and 'barrel' are defined in section 613A(e). The term 'equivalent' in relation to natural gas is defined as 6,000 cubic feet of natural gas to 1 barrel of crude oil. Production attribution for a marginal well with multiple owners is based on each owner's revenue interest. Operating interest is required to claim any credit on attributable production. The marginal oil and gas well production credit is only available to the holder of an operating interest. No credit is allowed if the well is eligible for another credit. The credit is treated as a business credit and can be used against regular and minimum tax. The marginal oil and gas well production credit can be used against regular and minimum tax. Special rules apply to this credit, treating it separately from other credits. The marginal oil and gas well production credit can be used against regular and minimum tax, with special rules applying to treat it separately from other credits. Amendments have been made to section 38(c)(2)(A)(ii) of the Code to adjust the credit allowed under subsection (a) for the taxable year. Amendments are made to the tax code regarding the marginal oil and gas well production credit, including changes to the carryback rules and adjustments to the credit allowed for the taxable year. Amendments to the tax code include changes to the business credit for oil and gas well production. Coordination with Section 29 is also addressed, allowing taxpayers to make an election. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of the tax code. The amendments made by this section extend the credit for producing oil and gas from marginal wells to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. Additionally, the credit for producing fuel from a nonconventional source is extended to fuels sold after December 31, 2002.
